Insights into the sandwich-like ultrathin Ni-doped MoS2/rGO hybrid as effective sulfur hosts with excellent adsorption and electrocatalysis effects for lithium-sulfur batteries Ran Zhang a Yutao Dong b ⁎ Mohammed A. Al-Tahan a Yingying Zhang a Ruipeng Wei a Yuhang Ma a Changchun Yang a Jianmin Zhang a ⁎ a College of Chemistry, Green Catalysis Center, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China College of Chemistry Green Catalysis Center Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou 450001 Henan China College of Chemistry, Green Catalysis Center, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China b College of Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou 450002, Henan, China College of Science Henan Agricultural University Zhengzhou 450002 Henan China College of Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou 450002, Henan, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Dual redox mediator based on a novel ultrathin sandwich-type Ni-doped MoS2/rGO with rich MoS2-defect accelerate the electrochemical kinetics for high performance lithium-sulfur batteries. The design of sulfur hosts with high conductivity, large specific surface area, strong adsorption and electrocatalytic ability is crucial to advance high performance lithium-sulfur batteries. Herein, a novel ultrathin sandwich-type Ni-doped MoS2/reduced graphene oxide (denote as Ni-doped MoS2/rGO) hybrid is developed as a sulfur host through a simple one-step hydrothermal route. The two-dimensional layered structure Ni-doped MoS2/rGO hybrid with heterostructure and heteroatom architecture defects not only plays a key role in adsorption of lithium polysulfide but also catalyzes on redox kinetics of sulfur and polysulfide species. Meanwhile, it can contribute to the large specific surface area for Li2S/S8 deposition, fast Li-ion and electron transportation, thus enhancing the electrocatalytic properties, as confirmed firstly by cyclic voltammetry (CV) results. Due to the adsorption-catalytic synergistic effect, the Ni-doped MoS2/rGO cathode exhibits high specific capacity (1343.6 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C, 921.6 mA h g−1 at 1 C), high coulombic efficiency and an outstanding cycle stability (with the low attenuation rate of 0.077% per cycle over 140 cycles at 0.5 C and 0.11% per cycle over 400 cycles at 1 C, respectively). This work proposes some inspiration for exploring the construction of advanced lithium-sulfur batteries through the rational design defects of atomic structure and electronic states of MoS2 as sulfur host. Keywords MoS2 Defect Self-assembly Electrocatalysis Lithium-sulfur batteries 1 Introduction With the attention to the environmental protection and the increasing demand for renewable energy, it is very vital to develop efficient energy conversion and storage devices to harness renewable and sustainable energy sources [1]. Due to the advantages of high energy density (2600 W h kg−1), high specific capacity (1672 mA h g−1), abundant sulfur resources and low cost, the lithium-sulfur battery has a great development prospect in today's battery system [2,3]. Despite its advantages, there still exist some obstacles in its commercialization: i) the insulating properties of sulfur and the final product (Li2S/Li2S2) will lead to a significant reduction in sulfur utilization and sluggish reaction kinetics; ii) the huge volume expansion (~80%) of the sulfur material will cause the cathode to be crushed; iii) the diffusion of soluble lithium polysulfide species (Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8, denoted as LiPSs) will move back and forth between cathode and anode under the action of electric potential, which is called “shuttle effect”. The undesirable effect will cause a series of safety issues [4,5]. Hence, it is essential to synthetize the sulfur host materials with high electrical conductivity, specific surface area, strong electrocatalytic and adsorption capacity for high-performance lithium-sulfur batteries. With the purpose of overcoming these shortcomings, previous workers have put forward a host of strategies to ameliorate the capability of lithium-sulfur batteries by designing the late-model cathode materials [6]. Large numbers of carbon-based materials with special pore sizes are used as the hosts of sulfur, including porous carbon [7,8], carbon nanotube [9–11], carbon fiber [12], carbon felt [13], and graphene [14,15]. These materials can restrain the diffusion of LiPSs by physical restriction, thereby increasing the specific capacity. However, the capacity still declines quickly and fails to meet commercialization requirement because carbon-based materials are nonpolar and cannot absorb the polar LiPSs species well. Recently, many materials with electrocatalytic properties have been used as sulfur host materials. They can improve the electrochemical kinetics of lithium-sulfur batteries by accelerating the conversion of soluble LiPSs to the final product of Li2S2/Li2S or S8 in the discharging/charging process, which increases the utilization of sulfur and greatly promotes the capacity of battery [16]. So transition metal sulfides, oxides, nitrides and selenides (such as TiO2 [17,18], SiO2 [19], MoO2 [20,21], NiCo2O4 [22], VN [23], Co9S8 [24], MoS2 [25,26], and MoSe2 [27]) have attracted more and more attention owing to the chemical adsorption ability of polar transition metal compounds to LiPSs species [28–36]. Among these materials, MoS2 received more attention because of its special structure and catalytic nature. The three S-Mo-S atoms layered structure is formed by a weak van der Waals force, which can provide many active sites [37–39]. Moreover, it has been widely used as an effective catalyst in the hydrogen/oxygen evolution reaction (HER/OER) [40–43]. Therefore, due to its advantages, especially its electrocatalytic performance, it has a great prospect as an advanced cathode host material in the application of lithium-sulfur batteries [37,38,44–49]. Nevertheless, the MoS2 material still cannot meet the high sulfur usage and long lifetime due to the poor ionic and electronic conductivity. Therefore, it is critical to design the nanostructure hybrid containing enhanced polar MoS2 and nonpolar carbon-based materials. Here, we first report an approach for designing a novel ultrathin sandwich-type hierarchical Ni-doped MoS2/rGO hybrid as the cathode through a hydrothermal process. The two-dimensional Ni-doped MoS2/rGO with ultrathin sandwich-type mesoporous architecture has a large specific surface area to accommodate higher sulfur loading and Li2S2/Li2S deposition. Moreover, owing to the nickel doping, the Ni-doped MoS2/rGO with unique hierarchical and rich MoS2-defects can not only limit the LiPSs in cathode regions because of strong adsorption ability (chemical adsorption effect of Ni-doped MoS2 and van der Waals force of rGO), but also accelerate the oxidation–reduction rate of sulfur. Consequently, the ultrathin sandwich-type architecture in the hybrid contains atomic and electronic defect states, thus improving the performance of lithium-sulfur batteries. As a result, the Ni-doped MoS2/rGO cathode shows an outstanding specific capacity (1343.6 and 921.6 mA h g−1 at 0.2C and 1C, respectively), an impressive long cycle performance with low average attenuation rate per cycle (0.077% at 0.5C and 0.11% at 1C after circulating 140 and 400 cycles, respectively). 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of MoS2 and Ni-doped MoS2 hybrids MoS2 and Ni-doped MoS2 composites at a variety of concentrations were prepared through the hydrothermal method. In brief, 0.5 g oxalic acid was dissolved in 60 mL deionized water with ultrasonic and mechanical stirring, then thiourea (0.4 g), (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and Ni(Ac)2·4H2O was added to the mixed solution (the total metal ion concentration is 0.013 mol L−1 and the atomic ratio of Ni to Mo is 3:97). Afterwards, the solution was put into Teflon reactor and kept at 180 °C for 36 h. The hybrid was collected through purification in deionized water and absolute ethanol. MoS2 was prepared by the same procedure without Ni(Ac)2·4H2O addition. The Ni-doped MoS2 composites with various concentrations of metal ion (0.005, 0.027, 0.05 and 0.1 mol L−1) were synthesized via the same step using different amount additions. 2.2 Synthesis of MoS2/rGO and Ni-doped MoS2/rGO hybrids Graphene oxide (GO) was made by the modified Hummer’s method [50,51]. Ni-doped MoS2/rGO was prepared by the hydrothermal method. Typically, the previously prepared GO powder was dispersed in deionized water (60 mL, 1.5 mg mL−1) under ultrasonic and mechanical stirring. Subsequently, oxalic acid (0.5 g), thiourea (0.4 g), different amounts of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and Ni(Ac)2·4H2O were appended to form the mixed solution. It was poured into Teflon reactor and heated at 180 °C for 36 h to obtain a black-gray cylindrical hydrogel. Subsequently, the hydrogel was soak-washed in deionized water and freeze-dried. The composites were labeled as Ni-MoS2/rGO (The atomic ratio of Ni to Mo is 3:97, and the total metal concentration is 0.013 mol L−1). MoS2/rGO was prepared by the same procedure without the Ni(Ac)2·4H2O addition. 2.3 Synthesis of the S@MoS2/rGO, S@Ni-doped MoS2@rGO composites All composite materials were prepared in one-step by a simple melt-diffusion method. Briefly, MoS2/rGO product and sulfur powder with mass ratio was 3:7, mixed and heated at 155 °C for 12 h in a tube furnace filled with argon atmosphere, excess sulfur on the surface was removed by heated 200 °C for 1 h. The product was labeled as S@Ni-MoS2/rGO. For comparison, the S@MoS2/rGO was also prepared by the same procedure. 2.4 Material characterizations The phase and crystal structures of the synthetized samples were appraised by XRD (Bruker D8 Advance, Cu Kα radiation) from 5° to 80°. The actual morphologies of the samples were proved by scanning electron microscope (SEM, Zeiss Auriga 500). Transmission electron microscope (TEM) was used to get the HR-TEM and mapping images. The sulfur loadings of S@MoS2/rGO and S@Ni-MoS2/rGO were quantitatively determined using the thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA, STA 409 PC/PG) at the rate of 10 °C per minute from 30 to 500 °C in argon atmosphere. The properties of the substance surface were studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using a single Al Kα (1486 eV) source on a thermal Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer. The UV–visible spectra for lithium polysulfide adsorption experiment were obtained by Perkin Elmer Lamda 25 UV/Vis Spectrophotometer. The Mo and Ni contents in Ni-MoS2/rGO were analyzed by induced coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) on an iCAP 6000 SERIES instrument. 2.5 Adsorption experiment To prepare the lithium polysulfide solution (Li2S6), sublimate sulfur and Li2S were added into the DOL/DME (1:1 v:v) solution in a glovebox filled with argon. The solution was stirred at 60 °C until a brown–red liquid (0.03 M) formed. MoS2/rGO (10 mg) or Ni-MoS2/rGO (10 mg) was put into the above solution to study the adsorption effect of the material on lithium polysulfide (Li2S6). Afterwards, the clear supernatant solution was gathered separately (~2 mL) for UV–vis testing. 2.6 Li2S precipitation experiments The Li2S8 solution (0.2 M) was prepared by dissolving Li2S and S (1:7, molar ratio) in lithium-sulfur electrolyte and stirred at 60 °C. Ni-MoS2/rGO or MoS2/rGO and PVDF were used to produce a slurry, which was coated on Al foil with an actual loading amount (0.5 mg cm−2) as the working electrode. Lithium foil as the counter electrode and Celgard 2400 as the separator, Li2S8 catholyte was added into the cathode region and the blank electrolyte was added into the anode region. Hereafter, these batteries were first discharged to 2.10 V at a constant current of 0.112 mA, then discharged at a constant voltage of 2.07 V for nucleation and growth of Li2S. 2.7 Cell assembly and electrochemical measurement The S@MoS2/rGO or S@Ni-MoS2/rGO powder, acetylene black and PVDF binder were dispersed in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent at a mass ratio of 7:2:1. The slurry was coated on the Al foil and dried overnight in vaccum drying oven at 60 °C. The electrode was cut into a disk with the diameter of 1.4 cm and the areal sulfur mass loading about 1 mg cm−2. The CR2032 coin type battery was assembled in an argon atmosphere glovebox with active materials, lithium foil and Celgard 2400. 20 μL mg−1 electrolyte (1 M LiTFSI in DOL and DME (v:v = 1:1) with 5% LiNO3) was added to the assembled batteries. Galvanostatic charge–discharge test was characterized using a LAND CT2001A multi-channel cell testing at different rates from 1.8 to 2.8 V (vs. Li+/Li). The cyclic voltammetry (CV) of cells was studied between 1.5 and 2.8 V with 0.1 mV s−1 by the CHI 660E electrochemical workstation. The electrochemical impedance (EIS) was recorded using a frequency range from 10−2 to 105 HZ. The symmetrical cells were assembled and examined to prove the electrocatalytic effect of the MoS2/rGO and Ni-MoS2/rGO materials. Traditionally, the active materials and PVDF binder (8:2, mass ratio) were mixed to form a slurry, then it was coated on aluminum foil and dried under vacuum. The electrodes were cut and used as working and counter electrodes, 50 μL electrolyte (0.2 M Li2S6 and 1 M LiTFSI in DME/DOL (v/v) with 1% LiNO3 was added into each cell. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) of symmetrical cells carried out from −1.0 to 1.0 V with 10 mV s−1 by the CHI 660E electrochemical workstation. Electrochemical impedance (EIS) was characterized with the same workstation from 10−2 HZ to 100 kHZ frequency. 3 Results and discussion The synthesis process of Ni-doped MoS2/rGO hybrid is described in the Scheme 1 . Briefly, some functional groups on GO can induce the reaction of the nickel salt, molybdenum salt and thiourea to fabricate novel sandwich-type ultrathin sheets (d ≤ 10 nm) of Ni-doped MoS2/rGO hybrids via a facile hydrothermal synthesis. The FE-SEM images of pure MoS2 and Ni-doped MoS2 hybrids with various concentrations show in Fig. S1, it can be discovered that both Ni-doped MoS2 and MoS2 (0.013 mol L−1) are the flower-like nanostructure, but the flower for Ni-doped MoS2 is looser than MoS2. It further indicates that the nickel doping has a significant influence on the structure and morphology of the products. More interesting, Ni-doped MoS2 hybrids at diverse concentrations of metal ion exhibit different morphologies. The hollyhock-shaped Ni-doped MoS2 assembled by the ultrathin nano-sheet can be seen when the system metal ion concentration is 0.005 mol L−1. As the concentration gradually increases, the morphologies of the composites show a more uniformly distributed rose-like nanostructure. However, it forms a layered stack similar to a cake-like structure when the concentration of the system is too high. The results strongly reply that the concentration is key to obtain the rose-like Ni-doped MoS2 nanostructure. According to Fig. 1 a, from the top-view, it manifests the two-dimensional layered nanostructure of the Ni-MoS2/rGO. The SEM images of MoS2/rGO can also be easily seen in Fig. S2. As shown in Fig. 1b and Fig. S3, the TEM image opens out the ultrathin sheet and the layer by layer structure of Ni-MoS2/rGO. Moreover, the HR-TEM image of the Ni-MoS2/rGO hybrid is displayed in Fig. 1c. It can be clearly found that the crystal lattice spacing 0.64 nm can be detected for the interplanar distance (002) plane of MoS2 [37]. Furthermore, the lattice defects (such as crystal plane deformity, spacing change and interruption) due to nickel doping can be clearly observed in the HR-TEM image. The exposure of active sites and edge sites of MoS2 will increase so that it has better polar adsorption and electrocatalytic capabilities because of many defects. The HAADF-STEM and corresponding EDX mappings of Mo, Ni, C and S elements are displayed in Fig. 1d and e, respectively. It further indicates the uniform distribution of nickel doping MoS2 on rGO sheets. It is generally considered that the Ni-doped MoS2/rGO hybrid with heterostructure and atom defect architecture would result in more robust interaction of LiPSs with Ni-doped MoS2 on rGO sheets due to the physical/chemical effect. After sulfur loading, the two-dimensional morphology of Ni-MoS2/rGO is not damaged and changed (Fig. S4). Moreover, the elemental mapping images clearly show the uniform presence of S, C, Mo and Ni elements on S@Ni-MoS2/rGO. It is most amusing that the distribution of S element is more concentrated than other elements. This further proves that the sulfur has uniformly distributed in the layered structure of Ni-MoS2/rGO. The crystal structure and composition of the pristine Ni-MoS2, Ni-MoS2/rGO and S@Ni-MoS2/rGO hybrids were characterized by XRD. As displayed in Fig. 1f, the peak at 14.4° and other peaks coincide well with (002) plane and other crystal planes of MoS2 (JCPDS 00-009-0312), respectively [52]. The broad peak at 2θ = 20 ~ 30° has clearly stated the rGO sheet [44,53]. Moreover, the diffraction peaks of Ni-MoS2/rGO (Fig. 1f) is similar to the peaks of pure MoS2/rGO and the diffraction peaks of nickel sulfides don’t appear. Also, the diffraction peaks in no nickel doping are consistent with the pure MoS2 and rGO peak patterns (Fig. S5). It demonstrates that the nickel atom does not evidently alter the crystal structure of MoS2. Raman spectra were measured to further testify the structure of the hybrids (Fig. 2 a). The as-prepared Ni-MoS2/rGO displays two strong peaks and two slightly weak peaks. The positions of two strong peaks are around 1345 and 1578 cm−1, which is consistent with the Raman shift of reducing graphene [54,55]. Additionally, the I D/I G value (1.14) of the Ni-MoS2/rGO is bigger than rGO (1.04), it reveals that the defect degree of rGO in the Ni-MoS2/rGO increases because of the hybrid formation. The slightly weak peaks at 374 and 401 cm−1 can be boiled down to E1 2g (in-plane Mo-S model) and A1g (out-of-plane Mo-S model) of MoS2 [56]. Thermal Gravimetric Analyzer (TGA) measurements were employed to determine the sulfur loading and in the hybrids. Fig. 2b shows that the sulfur content in each hybrid is close to 70 wt%, but the content of S@Ni-MoS2/rGO is higher than S@MoS2/rGO hybrid. The contents of MoS2 in the MoS2/rGO and Ni-MoS2 in the Ni-MoS2/rGO are calculated to be 43.54 wt% and 37.10 wt% (Fig. S6), respectively [57,58]. Moreover, the ICP results show the atomic ratio of Ni to Mo is 3.87%:96.13% (Table S1). The BET specific surface areas of Ni-MoS2/rGO and MoS2/rGO hybrids were obtained by Nitrogen adsorption–desorption test. The shape of adsorption isotherm is a type IV curve with a hysteresis loop under relative high pressure, indicating that the synthesized nanomaterials have a mesoporous structure. The specific surface areas (Fig. 2c) of the Ni-MoS2/rGO and MoS2/rGO are 185.8427 m2 g−1 and 161.2150 m2 g−1, respectively. The pore size distribution of the hybrids (Fig. 2d) also shows the mesoporous structure. The mesoporous structure with a large surface area will hold higher sulfur loading and provide enough space for volume expansion. This is consistent with the results of TGA analysis. To verify the adsorption capacity between the materials and LiPSs, the UV–vis adsorption measurement was conducted. 10 mg as-prepared hybrids were added to the bottle containing 3 mL LiPSs solution. After 16 hours, we collected the supernatant to test UV. By comparison with blank (Li2S6 solution), the color of the supernatant in the bottles containing MoS2/rGO or Ni-doped MoS2/rGO hybrid obviously faded. The absorption peak of Ni-MoS2/rGO (Fig. 3 a) is lower than MoS2/rGO and blank solution, which is found to be in line with the adsorption experiment results, indicating that Ni-doped MoS2/rGO has better affinity and enhances the adsorption ability of LiPSs resulting from the enriched surface defects caused by nickel doping. Additionally, symmetric cells were assembled to study the electrocatalytic effect of nickel doping on LiPSs. The CV profiles of the symmetric cells with Ni-MoS2/rGO or MoS2/rGO as the working and counter electrodes are shown in Fig. 3b. Comparing with MoS2/rGO electrode, CV curve of the Ni-MoS2/rGO electrode has a larger redox current, a higher reduction potential and a lower oxidation potential, showing that nickel doping obviously increases the electrocatalytic activity of the electrode. However, no current presented using the conventional electrolyte without Li2S6 as additive, authenticating that the peak current is caused by the redox of Li2S6 during charge/discharge. As presented in Fig. 3c, the Nyquist plots of the symmetric cells contain two semicircles, the first semicircle in the high frequency region should be attributed to the electron conduction process from the current collector to reaction sites in the electrode bulk, and the second should be ascribed to the electrochemical charge-transfer process at the electrode/electrolyte interface [59,60]. Li2S precipitation experiment is another important indicator that can evaluate electrode reaction kinetics of lithium-sulfur batteries. According to the previous literature report, the Li2S precipitation curves can be obtained using the potentiostatic nucleation measurement (Fig. 3d) [61]. These curves contain three processes: the reduction of Li2S8, the reduction of Li2S6 and the precipitation of Li2S. The Ni-MoS2/rGO electrode exists a shorter time and a higher current (237.5 s, 0.8693 mA) than MoS2/rGO electrode (715.5 s, 0.3335 mA). The obvious difference clearly proves that Ni-MoS2/rGO can effectively accelerate the conversion from liquid-phase LiPSs to solid-phase Li2S [62], which is consistent with the CV results of symmetric cells. Together, these results indicate that the nickel doped MoS2 has a stronger synergistic adsorption-electrocatalytic effect and enhances the redox kinetics on LiPSs because of more active sites [36,63]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was characterized to examine the elemental composition and chemical state of Ni-MoS2/rGO and S@Ni-MoS2/rGO hybrids. Fig. S7a and S7b show the mainly elemental compositions of the materials are Ni, Mo, S and C elements concerning their binding energy. In Fig. 4 a, the Ni-MoS2/rGO displays the main peak at 284.6 eV, which assigns to the C–C/C = C bond of rGO. Other three peaks are C-O/C-S (284.9 eV), C-O-C (286.0 eV), O-C = O (289.4 eV) [40]. From Fig. 4b, it can be seen that the Mo spectrum shows double peaks located at 228.8 and 232.0 eV represent Mo 3d 5/2 and Mo 3d 3/2 of the Mo4+, respectively. Another pair of peaks, which center at 229.5 and 232.9 eV, can be attributed to the Mo5+ [64]. This pair of peaks is mainly due to the distortion of part of the crystal lattice caused by Ni doping, which results in the existence of some high valence states of molybdenum in the material [65]. Furthermore, there are two peaks located at a lower binding energy of 226.3 eV attributed to S 2 s and the higher energy peak at 235.7 eV representing the existence of MoO3. The main reason is that molybdenum disulfide will be oxidized slightly in the air. Fig. 4c presents S 2p is fitted into three components. The two double peaks at 161.8 and 163.5 eV for S 2p 3/2, 162.7 and 164.6 eV for S 2p 1/2, are corresponding to S2− of MoS2 [64]. Another peak at 168.8 eV is assigned to sulfate owing to partial oxidation of the MoS2 in air. The Ni 2p two double peaks at about 854.3, 862.6, 871.6 and 880.8 eV show the existence of Ni2+ (Fig. 4d). What’s more, the present of the main peak at 854.3 eV is deemed to be NiMoS structure [26,66]. This provides evidence for the strong chemical interaction in Ni doped MoS2. After sulfur loading, the XPS spectra of S@Ni-MoS2/rGO are shown in Fig. S8. It can be seen that the peak around 165.0 eV can be classified as the peak of S8. To verify the role of Ni-MoS2/rGO in the actual lithium-sulfur batteries, the CV performance was tested. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO and S@MoS2/rGO cathode are compared in Fig. 5 . In the CV profiles of the first cycle, during the cathodic scan, the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode displays two reduction peaks at ~2.3 V and ~2.0 V, it is consistent with the conversion of the S8 to the soluble long-chain lithium polysulfide (Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8, ~2.3 V) and the further conversion to Li2S2/Li2S (~2.0 V). Interestingly, in comparison with S@MoS2/rGO cathode, the reduction peaks for S@Ni-MoS2/rGO shift positively and the oxidation peaks shift negatively in the following sweeps, in agreement with the CV analysis of symmetric cells in Li2S6 electrolyte. More interestingly, in the follow anodic sweeps, the anodic peaks of S@Ni-MoS2/rGO are divided from a high and narrow peak (in the first cycle) into three low and wide peaks (after the second cycle), as shown in Fig. 5a and Fig. S9. Those peaks are situated at about 2.4, 2.5 and 2.6 V, which can be associated with the oxidation short-chain of Li2S2/Li2S to the Li2S4, Li2S6, Li2S8 and S8, respectively [67]. But the S@MoS2/rGO cathode does not differentiate into multiple peaks at the anodic CV curves (Fig. 5b). These results demonstrate that the Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode will greatly facilitate the conversion rate of sulfur and reduce polarization during the whole process. Meanwhile, they also testify that the reaction kinetics of LiPSs can be greatly accelerated due to the MoS2-defects caused by Ni doping. Fig. 6 a shows the detailed rate capability of S@Ni-MoS2/rGO and S@MoS2/rGO cathodes at diverse current densities from 0.1 to 2C. The discharge capacity of S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode is higher than S@MoS2/rGO cathode, as well as the stable cycling stability at diverse rates. For the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode, when the rate raises from 0.1 to 0.2, 0.5, 1 and 2C, the specific capacity is 1152.9, 944, 844.4, 786 and 757.2 mA h g−1, respectively. A high reversible specific capacity of 992.4 mA h g−1can still be obtained when the rate is switched to 0.1C. It is inferred from the experimental results that the nickel doping can create more active sites than MoS2/rGO, which contributes to the fast Li+/e− transportation and electrolyte infiltration, thereby accelerating the conversion rate of lithium polysulfide on the Ni-doped MoS2 surface. Other rate performance of the Ni-doped MoS2/rGO synthesized using total metal ion concentration 0.05 mol L−1 (denoted as the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO-0.05) is also studied (Fig. S10). When the total metal ion concentration increases to 0.05 mol L−1, the rate capacity has a little difference at the current densities of 0.1C to 2C. The discharge specific capacity of the cathode prepared using the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO-0.05 is close to the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO synthesized using total metal ion concentration 0.013 mol L−1 at the current density from 0.1C to 0.5C. Nevertheless, the capacity decreases sharply with the rate increasing. The discharge capacity only holds about 200 mA h g−1 at 2C, the capacity is worse than the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO and S@MoS2/rGO synthesized using total metal ion concentration 0.013 mol L−1. We suspect that as the concentration of metal ions increases, Ni-MoS2 nanosheet will accumulate on the surface of rGO and the surface area becomes smaller than other materials (Fig. S11). This would increase polarization, reduce electrical conductivity, and slow ion diffusion, which decreases the electrocatalytic effect of nickel doped molybdenum disulfide. The galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles of S@Ni-MoS2/rGO and S@MoS2/rGO cathodes at different current density are displayed in Fig. 6b and Fig. S12, which further prove the superior rate performance. The results show that the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode has a faster redox reaction and lower interface impedance than the S@MoS2/rGO cathode. In order to confirm this fact, EIS was further tested to study the impedance characteristic of the samples. As illustrated in Fig. S13a, both the samples contain a depressed semicircle at the high-frequency region and a sloping line at the low-frequency region, which represent the charge transfer and lithium ion diffusion processes (Warburg impedance) [59], respectively. The diameter of the semicircle (charge-transfer resistance, Rct) at the high-frequency region for S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cells (43 Ω) is lower than the S@MoS2/rGO cathode (48 Ω), suggesting the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode has faster electrochemical reaction kinetics. Moreover, the impedance characteristic of the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode was tested after cycling (Fig. S13b). After cycling, the impedance of the battery assembled with S@Ni-MoS2/rGO decreased. The Rct of S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode reduces to 3.75 Ω, which is much lower than before cycling. It also shows that the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode is most favorable for the rapid transmission of Li-ion and electron. The cycling performances of S@Ni-MoS2/rGO and S@MoS2/rGO cathodes at 0.2C are shown in Fig. 6c. For S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode, it shows that the initial capacity is 1343.6 mA h g−1, the discharge capacity is 800 mA h g−1 (59.5% retention) after 100th cycle. Simultaneously the coulombic efficiency is higher than 99% from the 2nd to 100th cycles. By contrast, the initial discharge capacities for S@MoS2/rGO cathode is 1287.8 mA h g−1, with 52.7% (678.3 mA h g−1) retention after 100th cycle. The electrochemical performances of other Ni-MoS2/rGO cathodes with different nickel doping amounts (1% and 5%, molar ratio) are discussed in Fig. S14. It can be clearly seen that the 3% Ni doped MoS2/rGO cathode shows the best excellent performance. As illustrated in Fig. 6d, after four cycles of activation at 0.1C, the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode manifests an initial capacity of 937.8 mA h g−1 at 0.5C. Moreover, the average decay rate per cycle is only 0.077% after 140 cycles with the average coulombic efficiency over 99.3%. The long cycle ability of the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode also has made a great achievement (Fig. 6e and Fig. S15), which presents a much lower capacity attenuation of 0.11% per cycle at 1C and maintains 422.3 mA h g−1 after 400th cycle, demonstrating excellent electrocatalytic action on LiPSs. The excellent performance is better than other literatures listed in Table S2. Such an impressive performance illustrates the nickel doping MoS2 can efficaciously suppress the shuttle effect to reduce the capacity fading owing to the strong electroecatalytic activity. It is very essential to evaluate the performance of lithium-sulfur batteries with low E/S ratios [68]. Therefore, the capabilities of S@Ni-MoS2/rGO with the different E/S ratios have been further discussed. As shown in Fig. 6f, it still gets excellent performance at 10 μL mg−1 and 5 μL mg−1. However, the superior performance can be obtained when the E/S ratio is 20 μL mg−1 (Fig. 6g). The electrolyte will penetrate the electrode more effectively when the dosage of electrolyte increases, which may be the key factor leading to the difference of capacity. To achieve high energy density of lithium-sulfur batteries, the electrochemical performance of S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode (sulfur: Ni-MoS2/rGO = 8:2, mass ratio, Fig. S16) under different areal sulfur loading (one-side coated) is further discussed. As shown in Fig. 6h and S17, the initial capacities of the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode are 946.5, 957.9, 761.1, 407.5 and 458.9 mA h g−1 at 0.2C under different sulfur loadings of 2.81, 2.93, 4.03, 4.21 and 5.89 mg cm−2, respectively. In the high sulfur loadings, the stable performances of the Li-S batteries should be considered to have the excellent electrocatalysis toward LiPSs conversion on Ni-MoS2/rGO. The adsorption and conversion of LiPSs by S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode is shown in Fig. 7 based on comparing the CV curve of cell and the CV curve of symmetrical cell. MoS2 defects caused by nickel doping will significantly increase the active sites of the Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode, thus quickening the transport of lithium ions and electrons. During the charging and discharging process, it also can accelerate the oxidation–reduction process of LiPSs and improve the reaction kinetics in the whole process. The surface natures of cathode materials such as electronic conductivity and adsorption capacity for LiPSs are of great significance to exalt the capacity of lithium-sulfur battery. 4 Conclusions In the final analysis, we have presented a novel ultrathin sandwich-type Ni-doped MoS2/rGO nanoarchitecture as an effective sulfur host via a one-step hydrothermal method. The HR-TEM and XPS studies clearly demonstrate the defects of the nickel doped MoS2 uniformly anchored on the rGO sheets and the NiMoS bond formation. This well-designed defect hybrid can effectively inhibit the shuttle effect and improve the reaction kinetics due to efficient adsorption and electrocatalysis synergy in the enriched adsorption and electrocatalysis sites for LiPSs. Therefore, the S@Ni-MoS2/rGO cathode can obtain superior performance, including high capacity (1343.6 mA h g−1 at 0.2C), high coulombic efficiency (>99%), low capacity decay (0.077% per cycle after 140 cycles at 0.5C and 0.11% per cycle after 400 cycles at 1C). This well-designed and construction of defect hybrid cathode could be expanded to other transition metal sulfur-host materials, providing some inspiration for exploring the construction of advanced lithium-sulfur batteries. coredata.dc:description: The design of sulfur hosts with high conductivity, large specific surface area, strong adsorption and electrocatalytic ability is crucial to advance high performance lithium-sulfur batteries. Herein, a novel ultrathin sandwich-type Ni-doped MoS2/reduced graphene oxide (denote as Ni-doped MoS2/rGO) hybrid is developed as a sulfur host through a simple one-step hydrothermal route. The two-dimensional layered structure Ni-doped MoS2/rGO hybrid with heterostructure and heteroatom architecture defects not only plays a key role in adsorption of lithium polysulfide but also catalyzes on redox kinetics of sulfur and polysulfide species. Meanwhile, it can contribute to the large specific surface area for Li2S/S8 deposition, fast Li-ion and electron transportation, thus enhancing the electrocatalytic properties, as confirmed firstly by cyclic voltammetry (CV) results. Due to the adsorption-catalytic synergistic effect, the Ni-doped MoS2/rGO cathode exhibits high specific capacity (1343.6 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C, 921.6 mA h g−1 at 1 C), high coulombic efficiency and an outstanding cycle stability (with the low attenuation rate of 0.077% per cycle over 140 cycles at 0.5 C and 0.11% per cycle over 400 cycles at 1 C, respectively). This work proposes some inspiration for exploring the construction of advanced lithium-sulfur batteries through the rational design defects of atomic structure and electronic states of MoS2 as sulfur host.

coredata.dc:title: Insights into the sandwich-like ultrathin Ni-doped MoS2/rGO hybrid as effective sulfur hosts with excellent adsorption and electrocatalysis effects for lithium-sulfur batteries
